page.title: 07FARMING IN POTT SHRIGLET.
page.content: This is mainly grassland country rising from 400ft in the west to 600 ft. in the east. Most of the farms have milking cows, milk being collected daily, using the tankers of the "Milk Marketing Board" to take it to dairies for bottling & distribution Some is farm-bottled and sold to house holders. Young stock are raised for both milk and beef. Cattle are mainly Fresians for milk and Charolais or Hereford cross for beef. Since the coming of milk quotas in 1984, fewer cows are kept and on some farms sheep have been introduced to utilise the grass. On the higher land sheep have always been kept. Some barley is grown for stock feed. Hay and sileage are made for winter fodder. Acreage averages 80 to 100 acres per farm.
